abstract.text: Adds a new generic password to a keychain.

inlineContent.text: SecKeychain is deprecated

inlineContent.text: A reference to the keychain in which to store a generic password. Pass
to specify the default keychain.
The length of the
character string.
A UTF-8 encoded character string representing the service name.
The length of the
character string.
A UTF-8 encoded character string representing the account name.
The length of the
buffer.
A pointer to a buffer containing the password data to be stored in the keychain. Before calling this function, allocate enough memory for the buffer to hold the data you want to store.
On return, a pointer to a reference to the new keychain item. Pass
if you don’t want to obtain this object. You must allocate the memory for this pointer. You must call the
function to release this object when you are finished using it.
A result code. See
. The result code
indicates that no default keychain could be found. The result code
indicates that you tried to add a password that already exists in the keychain. The result code
indicates that you tried to add more data than is allowed for a structure of this type.
This function adds a new generic password to the specified keychain. Required parameters to identify the password are
and
, which are application-defined strings. This function optionally returns a reference to the newly added item.
You can use this function to add passwords for accounts other than the Internet. For example, you might add AppleShare passwords, or passwords for your database or scheduling programs.
This function sets the initial access rights for the new keychain item so that the application creating the item is given trusted access.
This function automatically calls the function
to display the Unlock Keychain dialog box if the keychain is currently locked.

abstract.text: Secure the data your app manages, and control access to your app.
An opaque type that represents a keychain.
Adds a new generic password to a keychain.
An opaque type that represents a keychain item.
The data is too large for the particular data type.
A default keychain does not exist.
Evaluate result codes common to many Security framework functions.
A pointer for accessing data of a specific type.
A raw pointer for accessing untyped data.
A pointer for accessing and manipulating data of a specific type.
